CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE:
This material is intended for the named recipient and, unless otherwise
expressly indicated, is confidential and privileged information. Any
dissemination, distribution or copying of this material is prohibited. If you
received this message in error, please notify the sender by replying to this
message and then deleting it from your system. Your cooperation is appreciated. 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
From: Susan Bradley <sb@askwoody.com>
Sent: Wednesday, January 17, 2024 5:21:12 PM
To: patchmanagement@googlegroups.com <patchmanagement@googlegroups.com>;
JBoettger@mcandrews-ip.com <JBoettger@mcandrews-ip.com>
Subject: Re: [patchmanagement] Feedback to Microsoft 
CAUTION: External Email From: sb@askwoody.com 
I'm guessing you meant to send this to someone else? 
I'll recap: 
Feel free to recap/copy and paste. 
Windows 10 has a separate patch KB5034441, Windows 11's version is included in
the Windows 11 cumulative update. 
It is attempting to patch the Windows recovery partition for a vulnerability
whereby an attacker can boot under the OS and gain access to the bitlocker
protected hard drive.  The problem is OLDER Windows 10 typically have a small
recovery partition and it's to the left of the c drive making it REALLY hard to
expand it and give it more room.  Newer Windows 10 installs put the recovery
partition to the right where you can easily expand the partition. 
With this update you need at least 250MB free space. 
Going forward you probably want to allow for a 1 gig recovery partition to leave
you room. 
Problem is you can't see how free your partition is, nor WHICH recovery
partition is in use without using a Powershell command  reagentc /info and then
a tool like minitool partition wizard to see the actual free space. On your
Windows 11 I'll bet BOTH recovery partitions are not in use. 
[cid:emfc7e21fb-130e-41a7-a0a1-c65e8fe62e8e@d44197a6.com] 
My actual recovery partition in use is number 4 
[cid:eme01260fd-5736-4927-9ca9-6e8708df977e@d44197a6.com] 
So step one - which partition - if any - is in use?  reagentc /info is your
friend
Step two use minitool partition wizard free to see how REALLY free that
partition is and what are your options for resizing
Link: https://groups.google.com/d/msgid/patchmanagement/CH3PR02MB968972EDC3B5E971E0EF6DF4A6722%40CH3PR02MB9689.namprd02.prod.outlook.com
